item.title: How to watch Apple announce the iPhone 17

review.headline_rewrite: How to watch Apple announce the iPhone 17
bullets: The company is expected to announce its iPhone 17 lineup, which could include a slimmer version, as well as updates for the Apple Watch and AirPods.
Taking center stage is the rumored iPhone 17 Air, which could replace the Plus model and would be notably thinner than any previous iPhone model.
It’s also speculated to include a 24-megapixel front camera.
Apple may also provide more details about the public release of iOS 26, which introduces a Liquid Glass interface that offers a more transparent look.

item.title: These 20- and 22-year-olds raised $5M from YC, General Catalyst to study online behavior using vision AI

review.headline_rewrite: These 20- and 22-year-olds raised $5M from YC, General Catalyst to study online behavior using vision AI
bullets: Within minutes, though, the 20-year-old Stanford dropout snaps into focus, walking me through how he and his co-founders sold one startup at 19, landed in Y Combinator, and raised $5 million for their next company, Human Behavior.

Launched just a few months ago, Human Behaviour is betting that vision AI can do what analytics tools like Mixpanel and PostHog have struggled with: give companies a real understanding of how people use their products, including why they convert or churn.

Instead of relying on manually tagged events or clickstream data, Human Behavior claims its AI watches real user session replays and generates insights, answering product teams’ most pressing questions without hours of instrumenting code.
“We could’ve done the financial engineering game because we got more offers with higher valuations, but we didn’t want that,” said the CEO.

Tech and VC heavyweights join the Disrupt 2025 agenda
Netflix, ElevenLabs, Wayve, Sequoia Capital, Elad Gil — just a few of the heavy hitters joining the Disrupt 2025 agenda.

item.title: Google’s best-ever 4K streamer is within $1 of its lowest price

review.headline_rewrite: Google’s best-ever 4K streamer is within $1 of its lowest price
bullets:
Google’s best-ever 4K streamer is within $1 of its lowest price
Google’s TV Streamer 4K doubles as a smart home hub with support for Matter.
Google’s terrific TV Streamer (4K) is the company’s best attempt at a streaming device yet, with built-in ethernet, an excellent interface, and smart home compatibility with both Matter and Thread.
Read our review.

item.title: Why I love my Kenmore canister vacuum

review.headline_rewrite: Why I love my Kenmore canister vacuum
bullets: Emma Roth is a news writer here at The Verge, “and for me,” she explains, “that means every day is different.

During the four years I’ve been here, I’ve covered breaking news and written about basically everything in the realm of tech, whether it’s streaming price hikes, the latest in AI chatbots, privacy issues surrounding age verification, and a whole lot more.”
Although she covers the latest tech news and products, it turns out that one of Emma’s favorite home appliances is a decades-old vacuum cleaner.
It may not be cordless, bagless, or ultra lightweight, but it has impressive suction that can pick up anything from crumbs to more stubborn pet hair.
It can also be a pain to lug around the house.
I’d be lying if I said that I didn’t violently yank the hose every so often to get this thing rolling around the house.
I just want to mention that I love the availability of replacement parts for this vacuum and just how straightforward it is to open up to clean the roller.

item.title: How Disinformation About the Minnesota Shooting Spread Like Wildfire on X

review.headline_rewrite: How Disinformation About the Minnesota Shooting Spread Like Wildfire on X
bullets: Within hours, the platform was flooded with wild claims about the shooter and her motivation, with everyone from Elon Musk, the site’s owner, to the head of the FBI and left-wing activists posting half-baked allegations blaming anti-Christian hate, transgender genocide, and white supremacy.

While other social media platforms were also used to share unfounded claims about the shooter’s motivations, X, under Musk, has become the perfect platform to supercharge the spread of dangerous disinformation during breaking news events.

The entire team tasked with tackling disinformation on the platform was first culled years ago, and now X's biggest users claim they are incentivized by the platform to share out-of-context clickbait content over verified facts.
As extremism researchers warned people against jumping to quick conclusions given the huge swathe of digital, written, and video content that needed to be analyzed, X users took very little notice.
In one of the primary narratives erroneously pushed immediately after the shooting, conservative influencers and politicians claimed that the perpetrator’s gender identity was at fault.
X’s own AI-powered chatbot Grok refuted the idea that transgender people disproportionately carry out mass shootings.
